title: nuevo
description: A short description of the post.
contents:
Who: Olivier Gimenez
When: 9am-12am on March 22-23-25-26, 2021
Where: Zoom
Schedule
An introduction to Bayesian inference [lecture | practical 1 | video]
The likelihood [lecture | practical 2 | video]
Bayesian analyses by hand [lecture | video]
A detour to explore priors [lecture | practical 3 | practical 4| video]
Markov chains Monte Carlo methods (MCMC) [lecture | video]
Bayesian analyses in R with the Jags software [lecture | R script | practical 5 | practical 6 | video]
Contrast scientific hypotheses with model selection [lecture | practical 7 | video]
Heterogeneity and multilevel models (aka mixed models) [lecture | R script | practical 8 | practical 9 | video]
Learning objectives
Try and demystify Bayesian statistics, and MCMC methods
Make the difference between Bayesian and Frequentist analyses
Understand the Methods section of a paper that does Bayesian stuff
Run Bayesian analyses with R (in Jags)
Requirements
You need to have R and RStudio installed
Download Jags from sourceforge and install it
Install the following R packages: tidyverse, here, lme4, visreg, lattice and R2jags. You can install them all at once by running the following code in the R command line:


install.packages(c("tidyverse", "R2jags", "here", "lme4", "visreg", "lattice"))



Credits
Many slides are from a workshop we used to run a loooong time ago with Ruth King, Byron Morgan and Steve Brooks. I also re-used or adapted slides by Richard McElreath, Kerrie Mengersen, Francisco Rodriguez Sanchez, Jim Albert and Jingchen Hu, Tristan Marh, Jason Matthiopoulos, a paper by Michael McCarthy and Pip Masters, AndrÃ©s Lopez-Sepulcre and John Kruschkeâ€™ book cover. The sources for the images are James Kulich, Matt Buck, xkcd and Mike West.
Corrections
If you spot a typo or an error, find a bug, want to suggest changes, or have trouble running the code, please file an issue or get back to me
